questions.text: A 39-week male is delivered apnoeic with poor tone. HR 90/min, pre-ductal SpO₂ 62% at 1 min despite warming/positioning. PPV is indicated. Which oxygen concentration should be started for PPV?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct oxygen concentration for initiating PPV in term and late preterm newborns (≥35 weeks) is 21% oxygen. This is because room air provides adequate oxygenation without causing oxidative stress. Higher concentrations of oxygen at birth can lead to free radical injury, delayed cardiovascular transition, and worse long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes.

Neonatal Resuscitation Program

  • Initial steps: Dry, warm, stimulate, position airway, and suction if needed (mouth before nose).
  • Golden minute: PPV should be started within 1 minute if the infant is not breathing or HR <100 bpm.
  • Oxygen concentration:
    • ≥35 weeks: Start PPV with 21% oxygen.
    • <35 weeks: Start PPV with 21-30% oxygen.
    • 100% oxygen: Reserved for intubation and chest compressions.
  • MR SOPA steps if PPV is ineffective: Mask adjustment, Reposition airway, Suction, Open mouth, Pressure increase, Alternate airway.
  • Chest compressions: Start if HR <60 despite 30 seconds of effective PPV. Use 100% oxygen with 3:1 compression to ventilation ratio.
  • Epinephrine: If HR <60 after compressions and PPV. Preferred route is umbilical venous access.
  • Meconium-stained amniotic fluid: Non-vigorous babies → resuscitate with PPV, not suctioning.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

100% oxygen (Option A): Incorrect because 100% oxygen is not recommended for initial resuscitation. It is specifically reserved for advanced interventions like chest compressions and intubation, as starting with pure oxygen may cause hyperoxia and oxidative stress.

30% oxygen (Option C): Incorrect because this concentration is used for preterm infants <35 weeks, not for a term infant as in this case.

50% oxygen (Option D): Incorrect because this is not part of the NRP algorithm. Intermediate concentrations like 40-60% are not recommended for initial PPV and lack evidence for safety or efficacy.

Key Takeaway

For term and late preterm newborns (≥35 weeks), positive pressure ventilation should always be initiated with room air (21% oxygen).

choices.text: Rapid increase in dietary protein during rehabilitation
Increased intracranial pressure due to fluid shifts

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with severe acute malnutrition is started on nutritional rehabilitation. On the 5th day, the child develops sudden altered sensorium. Laboratory tests show no major electrolyte imbalance, and fundoscopy is normal. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is Kahn's syndrome, an encephalopathy-like condition seen in early phases of nutritional rehabilitation of SAM.
  • It is not caused by electrolyte disturbances or raised intracranial pressure, but rather sudden introduction of high protein intake during refeeding.
  • It is self-limiting and managed conservatively by balancing protein and calories.

Nutritional Rehabilitation Phenomena

  • Kahn's syndrome: Altered sensorium in early rehab; due to excess protein; self-limited.
  • Refeeding syndrome: Caused by insulin-driven shifts → ↓ phosphate, ↓ potassium, ↓ magnesium; causes arrhythmia, CCF, seizures.
  • Nutritional recovery syndrome (Gomez): Excess protein later in rehab → ascites, HSM, gynecomastia, eosinophilia.
  • Pseudotumor cerebri: Raised ICP in early rehab → papilledema, headache, vomiting.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Increased intracranial pressure due to fluid shifts (Option B): Would cause papilledema and headache, as in pseudotumor cerebri, which was not seen here.

Severe hypophosphatemia causing neuronal dysfunction (Option C): Seen in refeeding syndrome; associated with seizures, cardiac failure, and arrhythmias, not isolated encephalopathy with normal labs.

Vitamin A toxicity following supplementation (Option D): Causes raised ICP, vomiting, irritability, papilledema; inconsistent with this case as fundoscopy was normal.

Key Takeaway:

Altered sensorium without electrolyte abnormality or papilledema during early rehabilitation of SAM is most consistent with Kahn's syndrome, caused by rapid protein introduction.

questions.text: A term newborn is delivered with good respiratory effort and loud cry. The heart rate is 140/min, and the infant shows active movement with flexion of all limbs. Despite oxygen administration, the baby remains centrally cyanosed. What is the most likely Apgar score at 1 minute?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Apgar scoring at 1 minute:
    • Heart rate >100 = 2 points
    • Respiratory effort good cry = 2 points
    • Muscle tone active = 2 points
    • Reflex irritability normal = 2 points
    • Color persistent central cyanosis = 0 points
    • Total = 8
  • The score is reduced only because of cyanosis, even though other parameters are normal. Persistent central cyanosis despite oxygen suggests cyanotic congenital heart disease (e.g., Tetralogy of Fallot, Transposition of Great Arteries).

Neonatal Resuscitation Program / Apgar Notes

  • Apgar score is calculated at 1 and 5 minutes (extended to 10, 15, 20 minutes if resuscitation is ongoing).
  • It is not used to guide resuscitation but serves to assess condition and prognosis.
  • A score of 7 or above is considered normal.
  • Persistent cyanosis despite good heart rate and respiration suggests cyanotic CHD like TOF or TGA.

Key Takeaway:

Apgar scores may be reduced in cyanotic congenital heart disease solely due to abnormal color, even when other parameters are normal. Persistent cyanosis despite good cry and heart rate strongly suggests TOF or other cyanotic CHDs.

choices.text: Appearance of jaundice on day 2 of life
Peak bilirubin at day 5 with spontaneous decline
Conjugated bilirubin comprising 30% of total serum bilirubin

questions.text: A term neonate develops visible jaundice on day 3 of life. Total serum bilirubin rises at a rate of 0.15 mg/dL/hr, and examination shows no staining of palms or soles. The infant is feeding well, has no hepatosplenomegaly, and neurologic examination is normal. Which of the following findings, if present, would most strongly suggest that this jaundice is pathological rather than physiological?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Physiological jaundice is always unconjugated, appears after 24 hrs (usually day 2-3), peaks by day 5-6, and resolves spontaneously within 2-3 weeks.
  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a neonate is always abnormal and strongly suggests pathological jaundice (eg, neonatal cholestasis, biliary atresia, metabolic disorders, infections).
  • Hence, the presence of conjugated bilirubin ≥20% of total (or >2 mg/dL if total <5 mg/dL) is a clear red flag.

Physiological vs Pathological Jaundice Notes

  • Physiological jaundice:
    • Onset: 24-72 hrs
    • Peak: Day 3-5 (term), day 5-7 (preterm)
    • Always unconjugated
    • No CNS involvement, no palms/soles staining
    • Resolves by 2-3 weeks
  • Pathological jaundice (red flags):
    • Appearance <24 hrs
    • Rapid rise (>0.2 mg/dL/hr or >5 mg/dL/day)
    • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia
    • Persistence >2 weeks (term) or >3 weeks (preterm)
    • Associated hepatosplenomegaly, encephalopathy, palms/soles staining

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Appearance of jaundice on day 2 of life (Option A): This is consistent with physiological jaundice, not pathological.

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia without CNS signs (Option B): Again, fits physiological jaundice; pathology requires conjugated bilirubin or red-flag features.

Peak bilirubin at day 5 with spontaneous decline (Option C): This describes the natural course of physiological jaundice.

Key Takeaway:

Any conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in neonates is pathological and warrants evaluation for cholestasis, metabolic or infectious causes, unlike physiological jaundice which is always unconjugated and self-limited.

choices.text: Stop breastfeeding and recheck TSB after 24 hours

questions.text: A 36-hour-old term neonate, born to a healthy mother, is noted to be visibly icteric. Total serum bilirubin (TSB) is measured at 11 mg/dL. The baby is otherwise feeding well, active, and has no hepatosplenomegaly or encephalopathy. According to practical neonatal jaundice management guidelines, what is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a term baby, phototherapy is indicated if TSB >10 mg/dL at 24 hrs, >13 mg/dL at 48 hrs, >15 mg/dL at 72 hrs, and >18 mg/dL at ≥96 hrs.
  • In this case, the baby is 36 hours old with TSB 11 mg/dL, which exceeds the threshold (>10 mg/dL for 24 hrs). Thus, phototherapy is the most appropriate next step.
  • Breastfeeding should not be stopped in physiological or early jaundice; only supportive management and monitoring are required alongside phototherapy.

Phototherapy

  • Principle: Uses blue-green light (460-490 nm) with irradiance >30 µW/cm²/nm, converts lipophilic unconjugated bilirubin into water-soluble isomers (lumirubin via structural isomerization is the most important).
  • Mechanisms:
    • Structural isomerization → lumirubin (excreted in urine/bile)
    • Configurational isomerization → Z→E bilirubin isomers
    • Photo-oxidation (least important)
  • Indications (term babies): >10 mg/dL (24 hrs), >13 mg/dL (48 hrs), >15 mg/dL (72 hrs), >18 mg/dL (≥96 hrs).
  • Distance: 30-45 cm; LED lamps more efficient than CFL.
  • Side effects: Diarrhea, dehydration, retinal toxicity, temperature instability, bronze baby syndrome.
  • Limitations: Not effective in established bilirubin encephalopathy.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Observation only (Option A): Incorrect because TSB is already above the cutoff (11 mg/dL at 36 hrs >10 mg/dL at 24 hrs). Waiting risks bilirubin rise and kernicterus.

Immediate exchange transfusion (Option C): Incorrect. DVET is reserved for severe cases: TSB >5 mg/dL in cord blood, rise >1 mg/dL/hr despite phototherapy, TSB in high-risk DVET zone, or hydrops/encephalopathy. This baby does not meet those criteria.

Stop breastfeeding and recheck TSB after 24 hours (Option D): Incorrect. Breastfeeding should never be stopped in physiological jaundice. Only in rare breast-milk jaundice (late onset, persistent) may temporary cessation be considered.

Key Takeaway

In neonatal jaundice, phototherapy is the first-line treatment when TSB crosses age-specific thresholds, while breastfeeding should be continued. DVET is reserved for severe or refractory cases.

questions.text: A term neonate, born at 39 weeks, is noted to have poor feeding and mild bradycardia on the second day of life. The nurse reports that the baby's trunk feels warm on palpation, but the extremities are cold and slightly bluish. Thermometer readings are unavailable. Which of the following best explains this clinical state?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cold stress is the early stage of neonatal hypothermia where core body temperature remains preserved, but peripheral vasoconstriction occurs to conserve heat.
  • This leads to a warm trunk but cold, cyanotic extremities, with early signs such as lethargy, poor feeding, bradycardia, and risk of hypoglycemia.
  • If untreated, cold stress can progress to moderate or severe hypothermia, causing metabolic acidosis, apnea, and potentially death.

Neonatal Thermoregulation

  • Cold stress: Warm trunk, cold extremities; early response due to vasoconstriction.
  • Moderate hypothermia: Both trunk and extremities become cold; systemic signs worsen.
  • Severe hypothermia: Core and periphery cold, neonate often unresponsive, high risk of mortality.
  • Prevention/management: Early recognition, skin-to-skin care, use of warm ambient temperature, and timely intervention.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Severe hypothermia (Option A): In this condition, both core and extremities are cold; the neonate is severely ill, unlike the warm trunk seen in this case.

Harlequin colour change (Option C): A benign, transient change where one half of the body appears red and the other pale; not associated with lethargy, bradycardia, or cold extremities.

Raynaud's phenomenon (Option D): A vasospastic disorder seen in older children and adults, not typically in neonates.

Key Takeaway

Cold stress is diagnosed when the neonate's trunk is warm but extremities are cold, marking the early stage of hypothermia. Prompt recognition prevents progression to life-threatening hypothermia.

choices.text: Wide fixed splitting of S2 with ejection systolic murmur in pulmonary area
Harsh pansystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border
Continuous "machinery" murmur at the left infraclavicular area
Harsh ejection systolic murmur with single second heart sound

questions.text: A neonate is found to have a minor external anomaly as shown. On further evaluation, which of the following cardiac findings is most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most frequent cardiac lesion associated with minor external anomalies like preauricular tags is Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD).
  • VSD classically produces a harsh pansystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, due to left-to-right shunting across the septal defect.
  • This makes option B the correct answer.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Wide fixed splitting of S2 with ejection systolic murmur (Option A): This is typical of Atrial Septal Defect (ASD), not the most common association with such external anomalies.

Continuous "machinery" murmur (Option C): Characteristic of Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), especially in preterm infants, but PDA is not linked strongly with minor external ear findings.

Harsh ejection systolic murmur with single S2 (Option D): Seen in Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), a cyanotic congenital heart disease, but no strong association with ear anomalies.

Key Takeaway

Minor external anomalies like preauricular tags may be benign but are important markers for systemic malformations. The most commonly associated cardiac lesion is VSD, which presents with a harsh pansystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.

choices.text: Persistence of proteinuria after 2 weeks of daily steroids
Persistence of proteinuria after 4 weeks of daily steroids
Persistence of proteinuria after 6 weeks of daily steroids
Persistence of proteinuria after 8 weeks of daily steroids

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with nephrotic syndrome is started on daily prednisolone at a dose of 2 mg/kg. Despite treatment, the child continues to have proteinuria (≥3+ on dipstick) after several weeks. At what point is this child classified as having steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS) is defined as the absence of complete remission despite daily therapy with prednisolone (2 mg/kg/day or 60 mg/m²/day) for 6 weeks.
  • Complete remission is defined as nil or trace proteinuria for 3 consecutive early morning urine specimens (Up/Uc <0.2 mg/mg).
  • Therefore, if the child fails to achieve remission at 6 weeks, they are labeled as steroid-resistant.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Persistence after 2 weeks (Option A): Too early to define resistance; some children may take longer to respond.

Persistence after 4 weeks (Option B): Still not the standard cut-off; some guidelines may monitor closely, but resistance is not declared yet.

Persistence after 8 weeks (Option D): Extending beyond 6 weeks is unnecessary and delays appropriate second-line management.

Key Takeaway:

Steroid resistance in childhood nephrotic syndrome is defined as the failure to achieve remission after 6 weeks of daily prednisolone therapy.

choices.text: Antibiotic prophylaxis for 5 years or until 18 years of age (whichever is longer)
Antibiotic prophylaxis for 10 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)
Antibiotic prophylaxis for 10 years or until 25 years of age (whichever is longer)

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with a history of fever 1 week ago, followed by migratory joint pain and swelling. On examination, he has a pansystolic murmur at the apex, but echocardiography shows no residual structural abnormality of the valves. His symptoms have resolved. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has had fever + migratory arthritis + new murmur → these fulfill the clinical features of acute rheumatic fever with carditis.
  • Since the echocardiogram shows no residual valvular lesion, this falls under carditis without persistent disease.
  • In carditis without residual valvular disease, secondary prophylaxis with benzathine penicillin is required for 10 years or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer.
  • This prevents recurrence and long-term valvular complications.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Option A (5 years or until 18 years): This applies only to ARF without carditis.

Option C (10 years or until 25 years): Reserved for patients with persistent valvular lesions.

Option D (Lifelong prophylaxis): Reserved for those with severe chronic valvular disease or post-valve surgery.

Key Takeaway:

  • No carditis → 5 years or until 21 years
  • Carditis, no residual lesion → 10 years or until 21 years
  • Carditis with residual lesion → 10 years or until 40 years (or longer, sometimes lifelong)

choices.text: Start empirical antibiotics with ampicillin and gentamicin immediately
Wait for blood culture results before starting antibiotics
Provide supportive care only, as the baby has no seizures or respiratory distress
Start vancomycin and cefotaxime immediately as first-line treatment

questions.text:
A 2-day-old term neonate presents with lethargy, poor feeding, and temperature instability. On evaluation, the total leukocyte count is 4200/mm³, absolute neutrophil count is 1500/mm³, and CRP is 8 mg/dL. Blood culture results are awaited.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The baby fulfills sepsis screen criteria:
    • Total leukocyte count < 5000/mm³
    • Absolute neutrophil count < 1800/mm³
    • CRP > 6 mg/dL
    • → Two or more positive criteria confirm high probability of sepsis.
  • In early-onset neonatal sepsis (<72 hrs), the recommended empirical regimen is ampicillin + gentamicin, covering Group B Streptococcus and Gram-negative organisms like E. coli.
  • Blood cultures should always be taken, but antibiotics must not be delayed while awaiting results.
  • Supportive care is important, but antimicrobial therapy is lifesaving and must be started promptly.
  • Vancomycin + cefotaxime is reserved for late-onset sepsis or in settings with resistant organisms, not first-line for early onset.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Wait for blood culture results (Option B): Not appropriate, as delaying therapy in a symptomatic neonate increases mortality.

Supportive care only (Option C): Supportive measures alone are inadequate; antibiotics are mandatory.

Vancomycin + cefotaxime (Option D): Used in late-onset or resistant infections; not standard for early onset.

Key Takeaway:

Early-onset neonatal sepsis should be promptly treated with ampicillin + gentamicin after obtaining cultures, without waiting for results.

questions.text: Match the following characteristic findings (Column A) with the respective syndromes (Column B).
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Miller-Dieker syndrome (17p13.3 deletion, LIS1 gene): lissencephaly with severe developmental delay and seizures (1-C).
  • Williams syndrome (7q11.23 deletion, elastin gene): elfin facies, supravalvular aortic stenosis, hypersociability (2-A).
  • Angelman syndrome (maternal 15q11-q13 deletion/UBE3A mutation): inappropriate laughter, seizures, ataxia (3-B).
  • Prader-Willi syndrome (paternal 15q11-q13 deletion or maternal UPD): neonatal hypotonia followed by hyperphagia and obesity (4-D).

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): In the treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis, intravenous fluids should be started before insulin.
Reason (R): Early insulin therapy without prior fluid resuscitation increases the risk of circulatory collapse and cerebral edema.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Initial management of DKA focuses on volume resuscitation because dehydration and hypovolemia are life-threatening.
  • Starting insulin before restoring circulation worsens hypovolemia by driving glucose and water into cells, precipitating shock and cerebral edema.
  • Therefore, fluids must always be initiated first, followed by insulin after stabilization.

Management of DKA:

  1. Airway, breathing, circulation
  2. Fluid resuscitation:
    1. Start with isotonic saline (10-20 mL/kg over 1-2 hours).
    2. Replace remaining deficit gradually over 48 hours.
  3. Insulin therapy:
    1. Begin regular insulin infusion (0.05-0.1 U/kg/hr) only after initial fluids.
    2. No insulin bolus in children (to avoid rapid osmotic shifts).
  4. Potassium replacement:
    1. If serum K <3.5 → replace first, delay insulin.
    2. If 3.5-5.5 → start replacement with insulin.
    3. If >5.5 → monitor closely, begin once K falls.
  5. Monitor glucose:
    1. Add dextrose to fluids once blood glucose <250 mg/dL to continue insulin safely.
  6. Complication prevention:
    1. Avoid overly rapid sodium/glucose correction to prevent cerebral edema.

Key Takeaway:

In DKA, fluid resuscitation must precede insulin therapy to prevent shock and cerebral edema.

choices.text: Immediate surgical excision of the lesion
Chest tube drainage of the cavity

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, productive cough, rapid breathing, and chest retractions. On examination, the child is tachypneic with hypoxemia and bilateral crepitations. The child is started on intravenous antibiotics. On day 6 of illness, the child continues to have respiratory distress. A chest X-ray (shown below) is obtained. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical features are consistent with severe pneumonia, and the X-ray now shows a well-defined, thin-walled, air-filled cyst in the lung parenchyma, consistent with a pneumatocele.
  • Pneumatoceles most often complicate Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia in children.
  • They are usually self-resolving and managed conservatively with supportive care and antibiotics.
  • Surgery or drainage is unnecessary unless there are complications like rupture, superinfection, or compression.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Immediate surgical excision (Option A): Not required; pneumatoceles usually regress spontaneously.

Chest tube drainage (Option B): Used for empyema or pneumothorax, not for an uncomplicated pneumatocele.

Bronchoscopy (Option D): Indicated for foreign body aspiration, not for pneumatocele management.

Key Takeaway:

Pneumatoceles in children are a complication of staphylococcal pneumonia and are usually self-limiting, requiring only supportive care and antibiotics.

questions.text: What is the appropriate timing for taking a blood sample to diagnose neonatal hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • After birth, the neonate undergoes a physiological TSH surge due to sudden exposure to the extrauterine environment.
  • TSH rises sharply within 30 minutes of delivery, remains high for 24-48 hours, and then gradually falls.
  • If a blood sample is taken too early (within 24-48 hours), it can give false-positive results because of this temporary elevation.
  • Therefore, the ideal time for neonatal screening is after 72 hours of life (commonly by heel prick), when TSH has stabilized.

Screening Strategies:

  • TSH-first strategy (preferred):
    • Higher sensitivity.
    • Detects primary hypothyroidism well.
    • Limitation: misses central hypothyroidism.
  • T4-first strategy:
    • Detects central hypothyroidism.
    • Limitation: misses compensated hypothyroidism.

Clinical Features of Congenital Hypothyroidism:

  • Neonatal features: open posterior fontanelle, umbilical hernia, edematous facies, constipation, hypotonia, hypothermia, macroglossia, rough dry skin.
  • Later features: growth retardation, delayed skeletal maturation, delayed puberty, myopathy, enlarged sella, pseudotumor cerebri.

Management:

  • Early thyroid hormone replacement is essential to prevent neurodevelopmental delay.
  • Start levothyroxine at 10-15 µg/kg/day.
  • Goal: normalize free T4 levels quickly; TSH may remain slightly elevated up to 2 years due to hypothalamic-pituitary axis reset.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Immediately from the umbilical cord (Option A): Not appropriate, because cord blood reflects intrauterine thyroid status and misses the postnatal TSH surge, leading to false-negative results.
  • 24 hours after delivery (Option B): Incorrect, because TSH is still very high during the first day, which can cause false-positive screening.
  • 48 hours after delivery (Option D): Although better than cord blood or 24 hours, TSH levels may still be elevated due to the physiological surge, hence 72 hours is preferred for accuracy.

questions.text: A 15-day-old, afebrile infant presents with a history of conjunctivitis that progressed to respiratory distress and pneumonia. On examination, chest X-ray reveals bilateral lung infiltrates, and a peripheral smear shows 14,300/dL (N 43%, L 54%, E 3%). Which of the following is the most likely pathogen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chlamydia trachomatis pneumonia of infancy has a very characteristic presentation:
    • Onset: 1-3 months of age
    • Insidious onset with persistent cough and tachypnea
    • Afebrile pneumonia (absence of fever is key)
    • Auscultation: rales (crackles) common; wheezing is rare
    • Lab finding: peripheral eosinophilia >400 cells/μL (not seen in other causes)
    • CXR: hyperinflation with minimal interstitial/alveolar infiltrates
  • Often preceded by conjunctivitis in neonates, acquired perinatally from the infected birth canal.

Thus, in this case → neonatal conjunctivitis → later afebrile pneumonia with infiltrates → points strongly to Chlamydia trachomatis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option B): Common cause of pneumonia in children, but typically presents with fever, toxic appearance, and lobar consolidation, not afebrile pneumonia with eosinophilia.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option C): Causes hyperacute purulent conjunctivitis in neonates but does not cause afebrile pneumonia.
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Option D): Causes atypical pneumonia in older children/adolescents, not in neonates.

choices.text: A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with bruising, petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis. His symptoms do not interfere with daily activities. Platelet count is 45,000/µL, and bone marrow examination reveals normal megakaryocytes. A diagnosis of mild Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) is made. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In mild ITP (minimal bleeding, platelet count >30,000/µL, no significant impairment of daily life), the best approach is watchful expectancy with patient education and counseling.
  • Most patients do not require immediate treatment unless there is:
    • Severe bleeding
    • Platelet count <30,000/µL with risk factors (e.g., anticoagulants, comorbid bleeding disorders)
    • Life-threatening hemorrhage (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage)
  • This avoids unnecessary exposure to steroids or IVIG in patients who can be safely observed.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Short course corticosteroid therapy (Option A): Indicated if platelet count <30,000/µL with risk factors for bleeding or moderate/severe symptoms. Not required in a mild, asymptomatic patient.
  • Intravenous anti-D administration (Option B): Used in Rh-positive, nonsplenectomized patients with significant bleeding, not in mild cases.
  • A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin (Option C): Reserved for severe bleeding or rapid platelet rise requirement, not for mild disease.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought with poor weight gain. His mid-upper arm circumference is 11 cm. On examination, he appears stunted with loss of muscle mass and subcutaneous tissue, including wasting of the buccal pad of fat. What is the grade of marasmus in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Grading of marasmus is based on the extent of muscle and fat wasting.
  • Grade 4 marasmus → defined by wasting of the buccal pad of fat, which represents the most severe stage.

Grading of Marasmus:

  • Grade 1: Loose skin folds in groin and axilla
  • Grade 2: Wasting of thighs and buttocks
  • Grade 3: Wasting of chest and back
  • Grade 4: Wasting of buccal pad of fat

Grading of Kwashiorkor (for comparison):

  • Grade 1: Pedal edema
  • Grade 2: Facial edema
  • Grade 3: Chest and body edema
  • Grade 4: Ascites

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Grade 1 (Option A): Only loose folds in groin/axilla, not as severe.
  • Grade 2 (Option B): Wasting restricted to thighs and buttocks, not buccal fat.
  • Grade 3 (Option C): Involves chest and back wasting, but buccal pad still preserved.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with painful bilateral swelling near the jaw and cheek for 3 days. His mother reports exposure to a mumps outbreak at school 2 weeks ago. Which of the following is the most common complication in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mumps complications vary with age:
    • Children: Most common → aseptic meningitis / meningoencephalitis
    • Adolescents: Most common → orchitis/oophoritis
  • Other complications: conjunctivitis, optic neuritis, pneumonia, nephritis, pancreatitis, thrombocytopenia.
  • SSPE (Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis) is a measles complication, not mumps.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Orchitis (Option A): Commonest complication in adolescents, not children.
  • Conjunctivitis (Option B): Rare complication, not the most common.
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (Option D): Seen in measles, not mumps.

choices.text: Isolate in the institution along with Vitamin A treatment
Home isolation of the child along with Vitamin A supplementation
Give MR vaccine, isolate the child and Vitamin A treatment
Only Vitamin A supplement, no action needed for the rash

questions.text: An unvaccinated child with fever, classic measles rash, Bitot's spot. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child has measles (highly contagious, SAR >90%) with Vitamin A deficiency (Bitot's spot).
  • Management = institutional isolation (to prevent community spread) + Vitamin A supplementation (to prevent measles complications such as pneumonia, keratomalacia, encephalitis).
  • MR vaccine has no role after clinical measles develops.

Vitamin A treatment in measles:

  • <6 months → 50,000 IU × 2 doses
  • 6-12 months → 100,000 IU × 2 doses
  • 1 year → 200,000 IU × 2 doses

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Home isolation + Vitamin A (Option B): Not enough, measles requires institutional isolation due to high transmissibility.
  • MR vaccine + isolation + Vitamin A (Option C): MR vaccine is preventive, not therapeutic once symptoms appear.
  • Only Vitamin A supplement (Option D): Does not control the spread of measles; isolation is equally essential.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child with acute diarrhea is being treated with oral rehydration solution (ORS). Along with this, which of the following is the correct zinc supplementation (dose and duration) for this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Zinc supplementation is essential in pediatric diarrhea as it reduces mortality, shortens diarrhea duration, improves recovery, and decreases inappropriate antibiotic use.
  • Recommended dose:
    • <6 months → 10 mg/day × 10-14 days
    • >6 months → 20 mg/day × 10-14 days
  • This child (7 months) → 20 mg/day for 14 days.

Treatment plan for dehydration:

Plan A: No or Minimal Dehydration

ORS is given after each loose stool.

Plan B: Moderate Dehydration

  • Give 75 mL/kg body weight of ORS in 4 hours.
  • Formula: Body weight (kg) × 75 mL = Total ORS volume.

Plan C: Severe Dehydration

Use IV fluids (Ringer lactate preferred; normal saline if not available).
